heycam: actually, there's a way
heycam: 1) make all your MathML text nodes into CDATA sections
heycam: 2) stick and with the image of the formula into annotation-xml
heycam: 3) hide annotation-xml using a selector that has an explicit namespace so it only matches if the elements really got assigned to the MathML namespace

I am curious what is really up with Google's H.264 license by the way; if they can really legitimately ship ffmpeg with H.264 support, it seems like Mozilla could too if it coughed up the money
I'm not really sure if their explanation makes sense or not though
othermaciej: it wouldn't work for downstream distributors
is Chrome (as opposed to Chromium) redistributable?
I think so
othermaciej: I meant not only redistributable as binary but redistributable as in compilining your own build and shipping that
*compiling
I think the point is that the patent license is for Chrome as a whole, not for usage of FFmpeg
I don't know the exact nature of Google's patent licenses, but it's unclear to me if source vs. binary would be a critical legal issue
I'm waiting for our lawyers to reach some conclusions before I comment further
I don't think you can build your own Chrome (as opposed to Chromium) but that's mainly due to trademarks
but even if Google's interpretation is completely right, I think it subverts the intent of the LGPL
I was surprised by their interpretation, such a thing had not occurred to me
but the legal issues are too subtle for me to have a useful opinion on whether is right
We've fought pretty hard to keep Web standards royalty free
I'm not in a hurry to abandon that fight now
One email from a Google person made it sound like it was a loophole that was closed in the LGPL3
I wish video standards had the same IP norms as Web standards
it seems it's that it's possible to be open-source in terms of copyright while still being freedom-deprived for downstream (e.g. by using BSD on code that infringes on a 3rd party patent)
even more, I wish algorithms and algorithmic techniques could not be patented
absolutely
ffmpeg itself seems to be a case of open source software that is freedom-deprived upstream
since it infringes on third-party patents and doesn't grant you a license
er, downstream
yeah but at least if you download ffmpeg from them, you get the same rights they have
and, in the US and other countries where software patents are valid
when you download it from Google, you don't
The open source community was up in arms when Novell appeared to have struck a patent license deal with Microsoft
GPL certainly seems less ambiguous about this than LGPL
since you can't link with non-GPL code which has a hypothetical grant of rights
I also believe the Novell move was seen as conceding Microsoft had legitimate patent claims against Linux, which was something that hadn't been convincingly demonstratd
afaik no one disputes that MPEG-LA has legitimate patent claims against ffmpeg (at least in countries where it holds patents)
it's true that the GPL and the LGPL are different here
I don't know why that is
but I always thought they were in the same spirit
modulo the virality
patents in Software and especially on open standards are kind of bullshit
wonders if the FSF is going to comment on this whole thing
I would be curious what they think, or a group like the SFLC
does anyone really think that the Linux kernel does not infringe Microsoft's patents?
the kernel is big and complicated
Microsoft's patents are many and broad
of course they intersect
it does make one wonder why Microsoft won't cite specifics in public
I've never understood why Microsoft hasn't gone on an all-out patent attack on free software
I would have
Maybe they're not evil?
maybe they really don't have any patents that are all that good
neither of those options seem credible
maybe they don't want IBM to sue them?
seems like a risk worth taking, they can always settle with IBM for the right amount of money
maybe they fear antitrust litigation
Maybe they fear precipitating change in the whole patent system
though, I heard a recent story to the effect that Microsoft was threatening and pressuring WinMobile handset vendors who bundled a non-Pocket IE browser
antitrust maybe...
for a while I thought they might be holding fire so that the EU didn't get spooked away from formalizing software patents
but that receded
my brother is a patent attourney, a partner in the law firm that handles Microsoft's NZ work
you can imagine what our family gatherings are like
that must be... interesting

Philip`: Where is the code? I have no intentions to make changes I just want to know if it makes more sense to me than last time I looked at it...
jgraham: There's some version at http://canvex.lazyilluminati.com/svn/tokeniser/ which might (or might not) be close to the latest version that exists
test_gen.ml is the bit that generates tests, based on the interpreter in tokeniser_interp.ml which executes the algorithm in tokeniser_spec.ml
Hmm, I'm not entirely certain that any of it makes sense to me
the tokenizer alone seems to have over 50 different errors and warnings

I think test_gen basically has a list of test strings (initially [""]), then for each one it looks at the final interpreter state (just before it would consume an EOF) and finds all the 'interesting' characters for that state, and then constructs a new set of strings, and then trims out ones that end up in duplicate states of others, and then repeats a few times

Philip`: I mean the number of different error messages the V.nu tokenizer can emit

ezyang: Trying to get a single emitToken in Tokenizer, what do you think of adding a callback function and calling call_user_func in Tok?
That'll be slower. Why are you trying to get a single emitToken?
ezyang: So we don't need handling like setting PCDATA on end tag in every emitToken we have, nor removing duplicate attributes, etc.
I was under the impression that's why it was a function call
I mean for the tokenizer tests we have an entirely separate emitToken, quite possibly with different bugs to the real tokenizer.
Which is kinda bad.
Oh, I see.
I want to have a single emitToken in Tokenizer which calls another function, normally the emitToken method in TreeConstructor, but could be something else for the tests etc.
So, with SimpleTest, you don't have to write any extra code: you just partially mock emitToken in TreeConstructer and do the wraparound
But that impls TreeConstructor class which makes it impossible to run the whole test suite as then TreeConstructor is already defined.
No, you make a new TreeConstructer, and then you use our $builder parameter to inject the mock

summarizing:" summary has been around for a number of years, by this point whether it works or not should not be a matter of assertion from first principles, but from actual measurements.  Key questions to be answered: who should use summary?  are they?  If not, why not?  what should user agents do with summary?  are they?  If not, why not?"  Is that a fair summary?

accessi-spam, as it were

if there is a real problem (navigating complex tables), and if @summary is put forth as the ONE TRUE WAY to solve that problem,

shelleyp: no one test could be used for something that big, the microdata section involved hundreds of individual decisions each of which had to be based on research, implementation experience, discussions with authors, etc
shelleyp: for example, to test whether the microdata features as described actually solved the problems they set out to solve, i explicitly used them to do so
shelleyp: (most of that isn't documented in the list, i just did it in scratch files)
shelleyp: (some of it became the examples in the spec)

shelleyp, it may be that the evaluation process for adding new features (e.g. microdata) is different than the evaluation process for dropping existing features, since existing features can be better evaluated based on observations in the wild.

tantek: certainly the evaluation process for features for which we have a decade of experience can be far more rigorous
